content.description: Move up an easy slab section to a horizontal crack.  Find thin feet and crimpy handholds to pull over the bulging crux, then on to two more moderate bulges, and easy runout to the anchor.
content.protection: 6 bolts & 2 chains at the top.  It is possible to protect the move before the crux for peace-of-mind with a large stopper; also a large stopper or smallish cam can protect the runout after the last bolt on the way to the anchor.
content.location:
This is the next route to the right from

Servant of the Bones

.

Rap straight down.

content.description:
This route takes the fairly obvious, thin-hands crack through a bulge that's to the left of

Watusi Afterworld

.

Start by climbing an easy, vegetated trough below the crack (or the slab to the right), get to a stance at the crack, fire the crack, and mantel when it ends.
content.protection:
Standard rack. A single set of cams and stoppers should work just fine. A larger piece (#4 or #5 Camalot) may ease your mind when finishing the mantel. Head up and right to the anchors atop

Watusi Afterworld

(or one could probably top out and descend maybe climber's left).
content.location:
To the left of

Watusi Afterworld

is a corner leading to a dirty crack. This route is to the left of that corner. It's very obvious from the base of the crag. Rappel from the anchor of

Watusi Afterworld

. A 60m rope is sufficient for the rappel.

content.description:
This route is the corner directly to the left of

Watusi Afterworld

. Climb a slab below to the corner. The crack goes from hands to thin hands. After the crux, the crack is filled with dirt and leaves; I needed to do a bit of gardening with my nut tool to get some decent placements.
content.protection:
Standard rack up to a #3 Camalot should get you up in style. Rappel with a 60m rope from the

Watusi Afterworld

anchor.
content.location:
This is the corner just to the left of

Watusi Afterworld

. It's fairly obvious when you're standing at the base of the crag.

content.description: This climb can be done with gear or toproped.  Climb the easy slabs to reach the short, but challenging, offwidth crack.  Then continue above to anchors.
content.protection:
Large cams are needed to protect the offwidth. It shares two bolt anchors on top with

Cold Nipples and Busch

.
content.location:
This route is located between

Lean Into It

and

Cold Nipples and Busch

.

content.description: This is a one-trick pony of a climb.  Scramble up a series of unprotected ledges to the route's sole bolt on a slightly overhanging dihedral with a stemming crux. Simple climbing follows, reaching one cold-shut anchor (to the left of the small gully & dead tree).
content.protection: 1 bolt just in time for the crux. A 1-2.5" cam down low (before the ledges) and larger stoppers elsewhere.  Currently there's a piece of knotted webbing jamming up what might be a prime placement just before the crux-bolt.
content.location:
The next climb to the right from

Grateful Head

.  The ledges are obvious under the singly-bolted dihedral (lots of nice orange lichen on it).

The top-out anchor on this one is... well, you can move left and get to the

Grateful Head

anchor pretty easily. Lots of rope drag otherwise.

content.description:
Easier climbing begins just under a green painted, angle-iron hanger & becomes slightly more difficult approaching the crux, which is a well-bolted bulge.  Run it out after the crux to another green hanger, then on to the anchor.

The rock is rough and offers excellent feet.
content.protection: Five bolts to a chain & cold-shut anchor.
content.location:
This is off to the right of

Watusi Afterworld

& Expropigation. Look for a green angle-iron hanger.

Lower easily or rappel off of either of the anchors (the anchors for Expropigation are just to the left).

content.description:
Great Full Body is a reasonable chimney route, bordering on squeeze chimney. There are just enough holds to keep it moderate and just enough protection to keep it safe. A standard light rack of cams and nuts should do the trick. Look just to the right of the route

Grateful Head

for a shallow, body-width chimney. Climb this to a fork in the top, where one heads left instead of back in to some stacked rocks, finishing up and left to the bolted anchors on

Grateful Head

.
content.protection:
TR from the anchors on

Grateful Head

or take a standard light rack to lead it.
content.location:
Start climbing up a moderate slab just a few meters to the right of

Grateful Head

. Finagle in a few points of pro before stuffing yourself into the chimney where the rock goes vertical. Get established, plug occasional protection in the cracks in the back, and work your way up to the top, where it opens up. Exit stage left and over to the chain anchors on

G.H.

Rap 65' to the ground.

content.description:
Climb up a slab, over 2 lumps, and past a little pine tree. The crux is working out toward the edge of the south-face on moderately thin feet, going up, and over.

Hiro adds:

After you get up onto the rib, it's easy going, the middle of the route is the difficult stuff. Also note that there's a nice, healthy, little tree below the second (?) bolt (a pin actually), which gets in the way of the rope. I went right to avoid the rope on the the tree, and used a shoulder length runner to keep the rope away from the tree/rock. My partner went left of the tree (which I think is easier climbing) but spent the time to try to get the rope over and around the tree
content.protection: 5 bolts and 2 pitons lead to a 2 bolt anchor. One piton is "hidden" behind the small pine tree (3rd clip) & is well-served if extended with a sling.
content.location:
This route is the first bolted route to the right of "

Brutal Planet

," the obvious crack toward the left side of the formation.

content.protection: The guidebook gave this climb an R rating. I brought a #5 Camalot along and felt like it was one of the better protected climbs at the crag.
content.location:
This is just left of the sport route

Lean Into It

. It is a pretty obvious chimney feature.

content.description:
Climb the thin crack 10 feet from the leftmost route on the formation (called Ground Zero in Gillett's guide).

It is a solid finger crack, though it has very sharp edges. The crux in the second portion of the finger crack leads to decent jugs and easier climbing. There are 2 bolts for a toprope and for a rap.

content.protection: A single rack and rope will get you to anchors on the climber's left.
content.location:
It is just right of

The Smiling Mortician

.

content.description: If you begin this from the tree, it is about 65 feet. Scramble up the slabs to the base of a wide crack/offwidth. From here, it is about 25 feet of right-facing offwidth. The crux is about halfway up the crack. Long sleeves and pants are suggested.
content.protection: There are no bolts on this one. Bring a light rack with LARGE pro for the offwidth, Big Bros. There is one bolt up top, and anchor with cracks nearby for the remainder of the anchor (#3 Camalot).
content.location: This is near the left edge of the formation. It is easily identified as it is a wide crack. Walk off to the left.

pathTokens: South Fork of St. Vrain Canyon
